qas.question: What does the bacteria give the worm?
What land is near the worms' first known location?
From where do the host obtain the hydrogen sulfide or methane?
When were the Galapagos Islands discovered?
What is the relationship between the siboglinid tube worms and the hydrothermal vents?
When were the symbiotic bacteria discovered?
Where does the symbiotic bacteria get nutrition from?

context: One of the most spectacular examples of <b5_0>obligate mutualism<b5_0/> is between the <b7_0>siboglinid tube worms<b7_0/> and symbiotic bacteria that live at hydrothermal vents and cold seeps. The worm has no digestive tract and is wholly reliant on its internal symbionts for <a1_0>nutrition<a1_0/>. The bacteria oxidize either hydrogen sulfide or methane, which the host supplies to them. These worms were discovered in <a0_0><b4_0><b6_0>the late 1980s<b6_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> at the <b3_0>hydrothermal vents<b3_0/> near <a2_0>the Galapagos Islands<a2_0/> and have since been found at deep-sea hydrothermal vents and cold seeps in all of the world's oceans.
